reviewText: I grew up with Seinfeld and became a huge fan! Unfortunately Seinfeld's run ended in May 1998.  Larry David picked up where Seinfeld left off and does it with a more mature tone.  I love the show and will continue watching as long as HBO is smart enough to sign LD up!
summary: If you like Seinfeld you'll Love Curb!
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: If you're a Seinfeld fan, you will enjoy this series. It's basically an R rated version of Seinfeld. The acting : isn't greatbut the writing is very funny and clever. You also have to overlook the occasional insertions by Larry David of his political views, which lean very heavily to the left. I think it would be fair to compare Larry David to Woody Allen: theythink it's very humorous to portray the Jew as a hapless, nebbish, kvetch and they both share a deep hatred of religion.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: You have about two episodes to fall in love or become repulsed. There is no gray area with this show's characters and premise.The writing and acting are just about flawless as comedies go, and the cast is nothing short of brilliant.Or, it's an exercise in ego and as overbearingly soulless as "Seinfeld" (which was written by this series' star and creator, Larry David), and the characters should be taken out in the rain and shot for their lack of humanity and interest in anyone's satisfaction but their own.You decide :)
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: Season four isnt the best (sorry that goes to the second one), but there are some great episodes in it. My favorite in Ben Stiller's birthday party and also the car pool lane. There are the not so funny episodes, but in the end season four is one of the better seasons. Still enjoyable (though will it ever cease to be?)
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: If you liked the first three seasons of Curb, you probably will like the fourth as well. Not all of the jokes work (do they ever?), but I was glad to see that despite the "Hollywood" bent of season four (where Larry gets help from celebs such as Mel Brooks, Ben Stiller, and David Schwimmer) Larry remains Larry. I mean, what other comedian would make a reference to the "Great Compromiser" Henry Clay? A bundle of contradictions, Larry is at once withdrawn and confrontational, overly conscientious yet also incredibly insensitive. Although I can't buy that any woman, let alone Larry's long suffering wife, would permit her husband a one-time fling as a 10th anniversary present, the running gag pays off because it sets up a series of encounters where Larry shows how inept he is at wooing women (remember, in season two he said he could talk anyone into anything, except getting women to sleep with him). And though I had doubts about whether the Producers plot would work, it does. Larry offends not one but two of his Producers co-stars as well as countless others along the way. There's a twist in the last episode that took me by surprise, and it was clever too. Sometimes the show strains too hard to find confrontations in everyday events. For example, I've never encountered a stewardess as rude as the one Larry comes across on his flight to New York. Nor would a black guy in real life walking past Larry's car instantly accuse Larry of racism just because he turned on his car alarm. But if some of the gags are forced, season four is as funny as the others. Larry might get more abrasive with each season, but he is no less amusing. Season four, as with the others, stands up to repeat viewing. And we get a one hour final episode that is much funnier than the last episode of a certain other Larry David sitcom. The best entry here involves Larry's efforts to avoid the rush hour crowd by picking up a hooker so her can use the much faster carpool lane. That episode might contain the most awkward, not to mention funny, drug deal in TV history.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: This is my favourite show but you can tell Larry is trying too hard to make the show more spectacular by throwing in "The Producers" story line (This is inspired by his friend Jason Alexander). Hopefully this is not his version of "Jumping the Shark". What made this show's chemistry so good is that it was low key, not showy and that he was rough around the edges which got him in trouble with fake Hollywood people - This chemistry is changing for the worst. Another thing I see that is happening is he's getting more stars on his show and it looks like younger stars to appeal to the 20 and 30 year olds.I HOPE THIS IS NOT TRUE but I have a feeling this show might be running out of steam. Kind of like the last season of Seinfeld where they just lost the passion they had of the show and became just another sitcom.Larry David said he called this show "Curb Your Enthusiasm" because of the high expectations people had about the show. The fourth season just curbed mine.
summary: This is the season where Larry "Jumps the Shark"
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: It is difficult to believe after seeing the first three seasons, but the fourth season of "Curb Your Enthusiasm" is even more outrageous then the previous ones.  The main cast remains the same, with Larry David playing himself, Jeff Garlin as Jeff Greene (Larry's agent), and Cheryl Hines as Cheryl David (Larry's wife).Once again there are ten episodes in the season of "Curb Your Enthusiasm"; however the season finale is a full hour long.  This season there are multiple plots which run through some or all of the season.  The season long stories include Larry joining a Broadway production of "The Producers", and the David's 10 year wedding anniversary and the gift that Cheryl promised him before they ever were married.  There are also smaller plots, such as getting kicked out of their country club and trying to join a new one, and insulting David Schwimmer's father.Each show has its own plot as well, which have Larry disrupting Ben Stiller's birthday party, setting up a blind man on a blind date, paying a hooker to ride in his car so that he can use the car pool lane, and much much more.  While there are a couple of points in this season where they perhaps go a bit far, on the whole it is the best season yet.This DVD box set includes 2 DVDs, which have all 10 episodes.  As with the second season, there are no extras, but when you have a show this funny, who needs extras?
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: I was glad I could contribute further to Larry David's wealth by buying this CD set. I hope he reciprocates and buys something of mine.  I have some mice for sale.  Anyway, no problems with this. Good Extras.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: While mildly put off by the vulgarity ending the 3rd season,we've found Larry ringing the bell again to start the 4rth year.Show is always best when it stays with his off-beat view ofsociety and its customs, and avoids juvenile and sophomoric humor.  Long live the avuncular, balding Jew!
summary: We keep coming back for more
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: Gotta love HBO and Curb!  This season brings back the best Democrat, LARRY DAVID and he does not disappoint!  My favorite episode is "The Car Pool Lane" where all hell breaks loose when Larry wants to use a hooker for the car pool lane to beat that I-405 Los Angeles traffic.  The actress that plays the character of the prostitute does a hilarious job in this episode.  It is also endearing to see Anne Bancroft in one of her last performances before she died.  [...]Oh, and get this dvd!
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: I'm actually really surprised that some consider this season not up to par.  I'd say that 3 of my favorite 5 CYE episodes are in this season, and this season is more over-the-top than the previous.  "The Car Pool Lane" and "the Surrogate" have me laughing the loudest in this collection, and the "10th Anniversary Gift"/"Producers" season subplots are great.  One of my favorite parts is when Larry calls David Schwimmer's dad on his cell phone to apologize (typical Larry David), and ends up cussing him out when his car is rear-ended.  Out of all four seasons, this definately has more laughs.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: This season is as strong as the last few and shows the calibre of Larry Davids amygdilla. Genius comedy is rare, what with the rubbish coming out the udders of mass culture, and all that, but thankfully, Curb Your Enthusiasm ranks with the brightest telly can offer. Larry David is an absolute genius like Ricky Gervais, that Heidegger bloke and Woody Allen.I love his writing and rank Curb with The Office and Cheers as one of funniest shows ever. My girlfriend and I can't get enough of Larry David, and even though he is 70 and should be taking it easy, he is still doing the do, like shouting at poor people and young girls, but in a funny way. (I hope that made sense). I just had a funny vision of Hank Moody, from Californication, playing Larrys character...  Let's write him a letter.What I mean is, Larry David's character is constantly harassed and bothered by poor people, that is, Hollywood's zero's who work in shopping malls and restaurants, and who dare to appear in front of Larry David's face; grrr!! Cue hilarious adventures. Hank Moody has similar adventures and both shows are set in Hollywood and its just as hilarious, which is the point. Many reviewers are offended by Larry Davids character, but they are really missing the point.A slight problemo. When Larry David's character is forced to sneer in an aloof but funny manner at a young nurse, it goes deeper than an old man sneering aloof because, I'm not being ageist (is that even a word), but the very old should be meditating, or whatever Hollywood types are in to these days; well its Larry so we can let him off! Hank Moody would be funnier mind, hence my Hank Moody ref.. Fortune favours the old tho.. This is the magic of Curb Your Enthusiasm. If you wanna get depressed, this aint the place to be. Its funnier that Notes from Underground you see (that didn't make sense too.. Oops!)So we see Larry David arguing with a waiter over why he should pay a tip, this would be funny if it wasn't for Larry David's own admission that he is indeed a millionaire, and so the joke hurt my sides as advertised. Larry David as a persecuted victim of those horrid Murlocks from H.G. Wells: The Time Machine, is a funny turn of events. Funnier still, Larry David hilariously shouts down aggressive female nurses who display annoying behaviour, like attending sick cues with those annoying sick people and LArry gets the once in a lifetime opportunity to humiliate a ridiculous shoe salesman (you have to see it for yourself). Larry David must be completely bonkers if he believes that laughing at workers is a source of insight; but it works, trust me, and this is why the man is a genius. Only in Hollywood can this be funny. We plebes will never get the chance to insult people like Larry David does and still be allowed in the community and this is why watching Larry David do it for us is so much fun. Those working class people are sooo 20th century and they deserve Larrys fire and brimstone. What's his next trick, bringing back sterilisation for the poor?Its the originality that I like. Larry David as a sneeringly repressed Hollywood writer, who sees himself as a crucified Outsider, with a dumb wife, young enough to be his victim, and a mansion with a high fence, is great. Larry doesn't just hate the poor, as he condemns the mind-set of the self regarding moneyed comrades he is forced to toil with, on a day to day basis. Give him an axe and Curb Your Enthusiasm is even funnier that American Psycho! Sorry to all the Ellis fans out there.Curb Your Enthusiasm is  a frikin masterpiece and Larry David is a great writer. Though you could argue that he only writes for millionaires and for those who believe that millionairehood is a mere few generations away. If you find shouting at the plebs and condemning their taste in shoes hilarious and if you yearn for Victorian values, but in a funny way, then you will love this. I loved it too, but I did feel guilty for doing so, so I'll let myself off!Curb Your Enthusiasm will go down in the annals of rib ticklers that reached the very heights of absurdist masterpieces. It really is brilliant, with superb production values and labyrinthine plot devises that always fall into very funny places. Though it is hard to feel any empathy with millionaires, but this show probably wasn't written for me and my girlfriend. Larry David has been filthy rich for so many years.Still a very funny series.
summary: The funniest series since the Office and Cheers but BETTER!!!!
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: dudes, what's up with this show?  it's, like, not even half as funnyas seinfield was.  but it looks like larry david is trying to be george AND jerry in the same character.  doesn't work.  i'd rather watch paint dry than suffer through this sh**.  are these all the bits that didin't make the sienfeld cut????  i'm out.  j.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: This is the season that the show jumps the gefilte fish. Larry as the star of B'way's THE PRODUCERS?! Extended guest appearances by Ben Stiller and David Schwimmer can't save (and may actually contribute to) this one from being the weakest season to date. (How much deadpan dourness can a viewer take?)But even when Stiller and Schwimmer aren't around, this season is on "coast mode." Too much reliance on forced, unfunny variations of David's now-predictable shock-value humor. Not enough Cheryl Hines. Even Jeff seems bored/tired.  If the next season's no better than this, everyone should call it a day and quit while they're still ahead of 90 percent of the junk on TV. They're entitled.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: This is hands-down one of the best shows of all time.  You will definitely appreciate it if you like Seinfeld, and it's hard not to love Larry David's silly antics.  All the seasons are great, but I especially recommend this one, as well as seasons 2, 3 and 6.  HILARIOUS!!!
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: This is one of the best series in TV that ever there was.  Larry David is excellent and whilst you feel sorry for him, you sometimes want to give him a good kick in the pants.  This show keeps you in stiches and it's the kind of show you can watch over and over again 'cause it always remains funny.
summary: Keeps coming up with the goods
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: Season Four is the greatest season so far and was pretty steady all the way through.  The Car Pool Lane is probably the greatest episode so far, right up there with season 2's The Doll.  The laughs just keep on coming with Larry offending everyone including Jews, Muslims, blind people, mentally retarded people, Holocaust survivors and Hasidic Jews.  Of course, he always suffers for his behavior but then always comes alright in the end.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: Great Show and loads of fun and laughter.  Larry David, You Rock.  Can't wait to get the Fifth Season.  We laugh so hard the whole neighborhood can hear us.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: I think it is absolute brilliant.  !  Mr. David is the world's best actor and everyone on the show is hilarious.  I hope it goes on forever !
summary: In a difficult world, sheer delight.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: Alot of people seemed to bash this season. I can see the meaning behind their reasoning.For the most part, Larry gets into the same exact situations he was getting into in the first 3 seasons. In fact, he gets in so much trouble this season that it is hard to keep up with the number of people who hate him. Still, it is funny. There are alot of funny moments where Larry embarrases himself. Also, Ben Stiller and David Schwimmer are pretty funny in the episodes they are in.Even though it does feel like Larry is running out of good ideas,  it's hard to resist his gift for pissing people off.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: Season four of Curb Your Enthusiasm is a satisfying continuation of the Larry David brainchild.  While the season lacks a classic episode like the seasons before, there is a common theme throughout the season.  Mel Brooks offers Larry David the lead role on the Broadway show "the Producers."  While Larry prepares for the show, he also tries to figure out how to cash in on his wife's tenth anniversary present.  Larry laughs in the face of political correctness while soliciting a hooker, buying marijuana, stealing a golf club from a coffin, and refusing to sit in the front seat of a car next to Ben Stiller.  The season ends in an hour-long episode (a first for the series).Curb Your Enthusiasm fans will love season four, but I urge those that are new to the series to start from the beginning.  While season three remains my favorite, there is enough to love about season four to watch it again and again.31. Mel's Offer32. Ben's Birthday Party33. The Blind Date34. The Weatherman35. The 5 Wood36. The Car Pool Lane37. The Surrogate38. Wandering Bear39. The Survivor40. Opening Night
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: The fourth season gets off to a strong start with two incredibly funny episodes featuring Ben Stiller, and a promising arc that places Larry as the star of Mel Brooks's Broadway hit 'The Producers'.Unfortunately, subsequent episodes are only sporadically funny (with 'The Blind Date' being a memorable low-point in the show's history), and the hour-long payoff 'Opening Night' is a broad letdown.Of course, this is 'Curb Your Enthusiasm' we're talking about here, so it's still better than 95% of the rest of the comedies on television... just "off" of its previous levels of quality.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: Larry David does it again...another great season!  I have heard a lot of people complain that there are only 10 episodes and therefore the price is steep.  I do have to disagree.  You really get what you pay for.  In my opinion, I'd rather have 10 excellent episodes (each worth watching again and again)  versus 30 crappy episodes of something that I don't even want to watch one time.  So far I have watched the episodes from the first three seasons at least 5 times.  There is no other TV series I own on DVD that I want to watch over and over again.  So I feel my money was very well spent.  I hope Larry keeps making Curb, for many more seasons.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: this show is hilarious !!  just like seinfeld..its basically a show about nothing.. but what makes this show unique is that its told  in the perspective of larry david.. in this series larry gets into one mishap after another and he always manages to tick off somebody  because of his way of thinking... its great comedy !  either you understand it or you dont  this show is not for everybody though.... the cast is great.. and you gotta love the music...you can picture  larry just cringing everytime you hear it  a class act :)
summary: this show gets better  and better..larry's misadventures continue
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: I love Larry David's brand of humor. Interestingly, many people don't. I didn't like Sienfeld at all, and yet he directed it, and yet this series makes me laugh constantly.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: Gets better every season. I never liked Ben Stiller or David Schwimmer much anyway.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: I just finished watching the season finale and I must say I am going to miss this show.  In the past few months I have watched all four seasons and this is the ONLY television show that almost every time leaves me with a huge laugh at the end.  This show is intelligent and so brilliantly simple and complex at the same time.  Do yourself a favor, WATCH this show, comprised of people who are at the top of their craft!
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: I would like to give this 5 stars, but I can't.  I didn't find the fourth season quite on the level as the first three, but I didn't think it was bad.  I am giving this 4 stars because of the lack of extras.  Outtakes, commentary, gag reel?  All of these would be great, but sadly are not on the dvd.  If these were produced more like the Seinfeld seasons dvds, I would be much happier.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: A lot of people pointed out the quality of "Curb" went downhill in the fourth season. I disagree. The "Producers" storyline with Ben Stiller and then David Schwimmer was just as great as the first three with some hilarious episodes. I read there are no extras in the set. A shame--so much could have been included, and the price is a bit steep considering there were only ten episodes. I got the first couple of seasons for $20,but the show is such a gem I suppose it is worth paying a little more..but it would have been nice to have those extras in there.ala Seinfeld.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: If you're new to CURB YOUR ENTHUSIASM, don't start with Season 4, unless it happens to fall in your lap.  Try to start from the beginning.  There is actually a subtle progression to the show.  Each episode contains both "self-contained" stories, and ongoing issues that develop from show to show, and sometimes from season to season.But I'm assuming that if you're looking at Season 4, you're already interested in or familiar with CYE.  Season 4 is a laugh-riot.  I think the season now has the perfect blend of Larry David, the unfortunate victim of circumstance and Larry David, the jerk who brings bad things on himself.On one hand, Larry tries to be a nice guy.  He always seems to enjoy the company of children, for example...in a genuine way.  He'll sit down with them and play their games and talk to them like they're actually interesting.  To him, there's no one who isn't worth talking with and trying to be friendly with.  This is an admirable trait...which always gets him in trouble.  On the other hand, Larry never knows when to quit.  He'll start on a subject (for example, he begins to suggesting possible "oriental-sounding" names to a secretary who is getting ready to adopt a child), and his riff becomes more and more inappropriate and the signals from the woman become easier and easier to notice, but he blithely rambles on...making an enemy whose disgust WILL come back to bite him.Often, Larry David is categorized as a misanthrope.  To me that's far too easy.  What I like about him is that he can go from charming and amusing and genuinely concerned about something (his interactions with his wife, for example) to an overbearing, overopinionated jerk in about two seconds flat.  We see him crossing the line, but he never sees it himself.  He thinks his complaints or questions are perfectly reasonable. (There's a great scene where he is waiting in a doctor's exam room for the Dr. to appear...so he uses the phone in the room.  Doctor [brilliantly under-played by Phillip Baker Hall] explains that the phone is not for a patient's use.  David just keeps insisting on knowing why.  He tries at one point to restrain himself...but he just can't help it...he's obsessed with getting an explanation!).The big story of the season is Larry being hired by Mel Brooks to take the lead in THE PRODUCERS on Broadway.  It's a bit of a stretch to believe Mel would make such a choice, but if you buy it...you're in for a real treat!  Ben Stiller appears in several early episodes and is very funny doing his "slow-burn" schtick.  The show has always been great for letting its guest-stars playing themselves turn their whole images upside-down.It's unfortunate that a typical CYE season only has 10 episodes...but heck, each one packs the laughs of 3 or 4 typical sitcoms into it, so from an entertainment standpoint, you can't beat this show.  Every episode makes me laugh out-loud many, many times.By the way, in case you don't know...these shows ARE NOT FOR KIDS!!!  They contain very frank (and funny) language and situations.  Strictly for adults.  But highly recommended too!!
summary: Justs gets funnier all the time!!
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: This DVD covers Curb Your Enthusiasm's best season.  Two words as for why this is: The Producers.  Most of the season's episodes center on Larry David's effort (or lack thereof) to master the role of Max Bialystock, one the two principal characters in The Producers.  His constants struggles with the rehearsals and his fellow cast and crew members are truly hilarious. As usual, Larry manages to somehow insult everyone in his path, and seems to lose little sleep over it.  In my opinion, the season's two signature episodes are The Survivor and Opening Night.  Buy this DVD, and you will never stop laughing!
summary: The best season of the series!
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: I have written reviews for the previous season of Curb Your Enthusiasm, and while they were positive, they were somewhat tongue-in-cheek.  I used a very unusual phonetic spelling and a very loosely coded slang that I figured hard-core viewers of the show would understand.  Well, I had ladies and gentleman alike explain that the reviews and the language that made them up were too "difficult."So I've decided to drop the comedy and play it straight in the review.  Unlike the preposterously overrated "Seinfeld," this show by Larry David strikes a chord that resonates much deeper than nonsense such as a soup-nazi (which is one of the weaker socio-political aspects of "Seinfeld" - a total disrespect for historical events that need not be trivialized through 'jokes').  Larry David does, in fact, portray a stereotypical fuss-budget (if you don't understand that slang term, I suggest you consult an on-line urban dictionary).  In doing so, he and his long-suffering wife Cheryl (portrayed sympathetically by the incomparable Cheryl Hines) make themselves two of the most relatable characters currently on television.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: The first three episodes of the fourth season of the brilliant TV series "Curb Your Enthusiasm" are a little worrying. They're both pretty solid, although overall, they don't quite match the quality of the first three episodes of the past two seasons. "Mel's Offer," although thoroughly entertaining and introducing one of the show's greatest story arcs, is a good example of Larry David stretching too far and trying too hard to be funny. The next two episodes are another example of an episode having a good plot, but relying too much on generic comedic cliches and physical slapstick for its humor. For a show that started off very realistic and life-like, this caused me to wonder whether or not season four would be as good as the previous two seasons.However, the season only starts off rocky. After that, it quickly gets back to the same quality it had before with an unheralded classic ("The Weatherman"), which is the first episode to have little-to-no 'The Producers' stuff in it, but has a storyline that's interesting enough on its own. Next up is a fan favorite ("The 5 Wood"), in which Larry gets Jeff and Susie kicked out of a country club over his five wood being in a funeral casket. "The Car Pool Lane" is another fan favorite (although slightly overrated in my opinion) about Larry finding an innovative way to use the HOV lane in order to attend a baseball game on time.The next two episodes are pretty solid, with the former featuring Wanda Sykes. Unfortunately, though, I think it's the only episode Wanda Sykes appears in. More of her would have been nice. After that is a brilliant episode with a sub-plot of whether or not a 'Survivor' game show member or a Holocaust survivor had it worse in their respective events. "Opening Night" is a series-best, with all the different sub-plots coming together in a brilliant second half, as well as an interesting plot twist near the end.Two things I liked about this season are that it was more coherent than the past three (having much more focus on 'The Producers' storyline) and that certain guest stars (especially Ben Stiller) were used very well. However, a little more Wanda Sykes would have been nice, and the first three episodes, although still at least good, weren't really up to CYE standards. Otherwise, another excellent season of an excellent show.Best episodes: "The 5 Wood" and "Opening Night"Season grade: A-
summary: Starts off rocky, but eventually gets back to the same quality as before
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: Great dvd and one of the better seasons of CYE.  Overall, a very funny season and worth the purchase.  I would recommend this season.
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4

reviewText: This season continues the awkward hilarity of Larry David's escapades. In this season he stars in a Broadway production of The Producers with Ben Stiller (and then David Schwimmer when Stiller can't put up with Larry), tries to follow through on his anniversary gift from Cheryl (after 10 years of marriage, he's allowed to have sex with another woman, if he can make it happen),  hires a Native American to do his landscaping (and help with another problem of Cheryl's), helps his secretary get back together with her boyfriend, accuses a weatherman of lying to clear the golf courses and much more.I watched 8 of the 10 episodes directly one after the other. The only reason I had to stop was 4 hours of any show is enoguh. This season is more cohesive as a season than previous ones have been. Story lines followed over into the next episodes more often than they have in the past.But overall, I think this was the weakest of the 4 seasons leading up to this point. I think that just has to do with the stakes being raised so high. In previous seasons Larry dealt with small every day things, whereas in this season he's starring in a Broadway musical and trying to hook up a blind guy with a date.That being said, it's still one of the funniest things on television. Larry still delivers the laugh. And any scene with Jeff or Cheryl is almost guaranteed to be hilarious. Surprisingly, the best guest star was a young boy playing Cheryl's nephew, who refuses to teach Larry a magic trick because he's "not a magician".There are no extras on the DVDs, but really what extras do you need when you have 10 episodes of Curb Your Enthusiasm?
summary: My enthusiasm for Larry David cannot be curbed
Title: Curb Your Enthusiasm: Season 4
